note_text:
INTERVENTIONAL PULMONOLOGY OPERATIVE REPORT
 
DATE OF PROCEDURE: 12/16/2025
 
CC Referred Physician:  Perry, Sandip Pravin, MD
3855 Health Sciences Dr
Hollywood,  CA 92093-0987
 
INDICATION FOR OPERATION:  Elizabeth Larkin is a 89 year old-year-old female who presents with lung mass.  The nature, purpose, risks, benefits and alternatives to Bronchoscopy were discussed with the patient in detail.  Patient indicated a wish to proceed with surgery and informed consent was signed.
 
CONSENT : Obtained before the procedure. Its indications and potential complications and alternatives were discussed with the patient or surrogate. The patient or surrogate read and signed the provided consent form / provided consent over the phone. The consent was witnessed by an assisting medical professional.
 
PREOPERATIVE DIAGNOSIS: R91.8 Other nonspecific abnormal finding of lung field.
 
POSTOPERATIVE DIAGNOSIS:  R91.8 Other nonspecific abnormal finding of lung field.
 
PROCEDURE:  
31645 Therapeutic aspiration initial episode
31624 Dx bronchoscope/lavage (BAL)    
31628 TBBX single lobe     
31629 TBNA single lobe   
31653 EBUS sampling 3 or more nodes  
31654 Radial EBUS for peripheral lesion
76982 Ultrasound Elastography, First Target Lesion
76983 Ultrasound Elastography, Additional Targets 
76983 Ultrasound Elastography, Additional Target 2
 
ATTENDING:  
Duane Johnson MD PhD
 
ASSISTANT:   none
 
Support Staff: 
RN: Rebecca Loman andWilliam Shakespeak
RT: Philip Knight
 
ANESTHESIA: 
General Anesthesia
 
MONITORING : Pulse oximetry, heart rate, telemetry, and BP were continuously monitored by an independent trained observer that was present throughout the entire procedure.
 
INSTRUMENT : 
Flexible Therapeutic Bronchoscope
Linear EBUS 
Radial EBUS
 
ESTIMATED BLOOD LOSS:   None
 
COMPLICATIONS:    None
 
PROCEDURE IN DETAIL:
After the successful induction of anesthesia, a timeout was performed (confirming the patient's name, procedure type, and procedure location).  All procedure related images were saved and archived in Media folder on Onedrive behind UCSD firewall, relevant images are also uploaded to PACS system or in the media section of the patient's chart. 
 
PATIENT POSITION: . 
 
Initial Airway Inspection Findings:
 
Successful therapeutic aspiration was performed to clean out the Right Mainstem, Bronchus Intermedius , and Left Mainstem from mucus. 
 
Therapeutic bronchoscope was parked in RML; lateral segment was engaged.
 
Radial EBUS was performed to confirm that the location of the nodule is Concentric.  The following features were noted: Continuous margin  and Absence of linear-discrete air bronchogram.
 
Transbronchial needle aspiration was performed with 19G Needle and 21G Needle through the extended working channel catheter.  Total 6 samples were collected.  Samples sent for Microbiology (Cultures/Viral/Fungal) and Cytology.
 
Transbronchial biopsy was performed with alligator forceps the extended working channel catheter.  Total 6 samples were collected.  Samples sent for Pathology.
 
Bronchial alveolar lavage was performed the extended working channel catheter.  Instilled 40 cc of NS, suction returned with 20 cc of NS.  Samples sent for Microbiology (Cultures/Viral/Fungal) and Cytology.
 
ROSE from procedure was noted to be:
Conclusive evidence of malignant neoplasm
 
EBUS-Findings
Indications: Diagnostic and Staging
Technique:
All lymph node stations were assessed. Only those 5 mm or greater in short axis were sampled.
 
Lymph node sizing was performed by EBUS and sampling by Transbronchial needle aspiration was performed using 22-gauge Needle.
 
Lymph Nodes/Sites Inspected: 2R (upper paratracheal) node
2L (upper paratracheal) node
4R (lower paratracheal) node
4L (lower paratracheal) node
7 (subcarinal) node
10R lymph node
10L lymph node
11Rs lymph node
11Ri lymph node
11L lymph node
 
No immediate complications
 
Endobronchial ultrasound (EBUS) elastography was performed to assess lymph node stiffness and tissue characteristics. Elastography provided a semi-quantitative classification (Type 1–3), which was used to guide biopsy site selection and sampling strategy. 
 
Lymph Nodes Evaluated:
Site 1: The 11L lymph node was => 10 mm on CT and Metabolic activity unknown or PET-CT scan unavailable. The lymph node was photographed. The site was sampled.. 4 endobronchial ultrasound guided Transbronchial biopsies were performed with samples obtained. Endobronchial ultrasound (EBUS) elastography was performed to assess lymph node stiffness and tissue characteristics. The target lymph node demonstrated a Type 1 elastographic pattern, predominantly soft (green/yellow), suggesting a reactive or benign process. Despite the benign appearance, TBNA was performed to confirm the absence of malignancy and to obtain cytology for diagnostic completeness.
 
Site 2: The 7 (subcarinal) node was => 10 mm on CT and Metabolic activity unknown or PET-CT scan unavailable. The lymph node was photographed. The site was sampled.. 4 endobronchial ultrasound guided Transbronchial biopsies were performed with samples obtained. Endobronchial ultrasound (EBUS) elastography was performed to assess lymph node stiffness and tissue characteristics. The target lymph node demonstrated a Type 2 elastographic pattern with mixed soft and stiff regions. Given this heterogeneous and indeterminate appearance, TBNA was directed at representative areas to ensure comprehensive sampling and to minimize the risk of underdiagnosis.
 
Site 3: The 11Rs lymph node was => 10 mm on CT and Metabolic activity unknown or PET-CT scan unavailable. The lymph node was photographed. The site was sampled.. 4 endobronchial ultrasound guided Transbronchial biopsies were performed with samples obtained. Endobronchial ultrasound (EBUS) elastography was performed to assess lymph node stiffness and tissue characteristics. The target lymph node demonstrated a Type 2 elastographic pattern with mixed soft and stiff regions. Given this heterogeneous and indeterminate appearance, TBNA was directed at representative areas to ensure comprehensive sampling and to minimize the risk of underdiagnosis.
 
The patient tolerated the procedure well.  There were no immediate complications.  At the conclusion of the operation, the patient was extubated in the operating room and Transported to the recovery room in stable condition. 
 
SPECIMEN(S): 
RML TBBX, TBNA, BAL
TBNA 11L, 11R, 7
 
IMPRESSION/PLAN: Elizabeth Larkin is a 89 year old-year-old female who presents for bronchoscopy for lung mass evaluation.
- f/u in clinic
- complete pred course and zpak
- f/u cxr
 
Duane Johnson , MD, PhD
12/16/2025

therapeutic_aspiration.location: Right Mainstem, Bronchus Intermedius, Left Mainstem

navigation_targets.rebus_lesion_appearance: Continuous margin, absence of air bronchogram

cpt_codes.description: Bronchoscopy; with EBUS sampling, 3 or more nodal stations
Bronchoscopy; with therapeutic aspiration of tracheobronchial tree, initial
Bronchoscopy; with transbronchial lung biopsy(s), single lobe
EBUS for peripheral lesion(s) during bronchoscopic intervention(s) (add-on)

lines.description: Bronchoscopy; with EBUS sampling, 3 or more nodal stations
Bronchoscopy; with therapeutic aspiration of tracheobronchial tree, initial
lines.selection_reason: Distinct therapeutic work (clearing mucus from RMS/LMS/BI) separate from biopsy sites.

lines.description: Bronchoscopy; with transbronchial lung biopsy(s), single lobe
lines.selection_reason: RML peripheral mass biopsy. Distinct from EBUS targets.

lines.description: EBUS for peripheral lesion(s) during bronchoscopic intervention(s) (add-on)
lines.selection_reason: Radial EBUS localization of RML nodule.

lines.description: Bronchoscopy; with transbronchial needle aspiration biopsy(s)

per_code.summary: Supported by EBUS-TBNA of 3 distinct stations (11L, 7, 11Rs). Highest valued code, selected as primary.
Supported by documentation of therapeutic aspiration of mucus from central airways (RMS, LMS, BI). Distinct from biopsy sites.
Supported by transbronchial biopsy of RML mass. Chosen as the primary sampling code for the peripheral lesion over TBNA (31629) due to bundling rules for same-site interventions.
Supported by documentation of Radial EBUS (concentric view) for the RML peripheral lesion.

global_comments: TBNA (31629) and BAL (31624) of the RML were performed but are bundled into the TBLB (31628) of the same site per NCCI principles.
Diagnostic bronchoscopy (31622) is bundled into therapeutic procedures.
Ultrasound Elastography (76982/76983) listed in header but not separately reportable with EBUS codes per standard IP coding rules; omitted from final billing.

outcomes.follow_up_plan_text: f/u in clinic, complete pred course and zpak, f/u cxr

note_text:
DATE OF PROCEDURE: 12/162025
 
CC Referred Physician:  Duane Johnson, MD, PhD
1 Happy Street
# 1244
Hollywood,  CA 92037-1300
 
INDICATION FOR OPERATION:  Tammy Adams is a 63 year old-year-old female who presents with pulmonary nodule.  The nature, purpose, risks, benefits and alternatives to Bronchoscopy were discussed with the patient in detail.  Patient indicated a wish to proceed with surgery and informed consent was signed.
 
CONSENT : Obtained before the procedure. Its indications and potential complications and alternatives were discussed with the patient or surrogate. The patient or surrogate read and signed the provided consent form / provided consent over the phone. The consent was witnessed by an assisting medical professional.
 
PREOPERATIVE DIAGNOSIS: R91.1 Solitary Lung Nodule
 
POSTOPERATIVE DIAGNOSIS:  R91.1 Solitary Lung Nodule
 
PROCEDURE:  
31645 Therapeutic aspiration initial episode
31629 TBNA single lobe   
31627 Navigational Bronchoscopy (computer assisted)
77012 Radiology / radiologic guidance for CT guided needle placement (CIOS)
76377 3D rendering with interpretation and reporting of CT, US, Tomo modality (ION Planning Station)
31654 Radial EBUS for peripheral lesion
31641 Destruction of tumor OR relief of stenosis by any method other than excision (eg. laser therapy, cryotherapy)
 
 
ATTENDING:  
Duane Johnson MD PhD and Hector Martinez MD
 
ASSISTANT:   none
 
Support Staff: 
RN: Kimberlyn Hill
RT: Christopher Reeves  and Philip Knight
 
ANESTHESIA: 
General Anesthesia
 
MONITORING : Pulse oximetry, heart rate, telemetry, and BP were continuously monitored by an independent trained observer that was present throughout the entire procedure.
 
INSTRUMENT : 
Flexible Therapeutic Bronchoscope
Flexible Hybrid (Pedatric) Bronchoscope
Radial EBUS
Ion Robotic Bronchoscope
 
ESTIMATED BLOOD LOSS:   Minimum
 
COMPLICATIONS:    None
 
PROCEDURE IN DETAIL:
After the successful induction of anesthesia, a timeout was performed (confirming the patient's name, procedure type, and procedure location).
 
Initial Airway Inspection Findings:
 
Successful therapeutic aspiration was performed to clean out the Trachea (Middle 1/3), Trachea (Distal 1/3), Right Mainstem, and Bronchus Intermedius  from mucus. 
 
 
CT Chest scan was placed on separate planning station to generate 3D rendering of the pathway to target.   The navigational plan was reviewed and verified.  This was then loaded into robotic bronchoscopy platform. 
 
Ventilation Parameters:
Mode	RR	TV	PEEP	FiO2	Flow Rate	Pmean
VCV	12 	300	12	100	10	15
 
RUL Mass: 
 
Robotic navigation bronchoscopy was performed with Ion platform.  Partial registration was used.    Ion robotic catheter was used to engage the Anterior Segment of RUL (RB3).  Target lesion is about 4.0 cm in diameter.   Under navigational guidance the ion robotic catheter was advanced to 1.0 cm away from the planned target. 
 
Needle was advanced into the lesion. Cone Beam CT was performed: 3-D reconstructions were performed on an independent workstation.  Cios Spin system was used for evaluation of nodule location.  Low dose spin was performed to acquire CT imaging.  This was passed on to Ion platform system for reconstruction and nodule location.  The 3D images was interpreted on an independent workstation (Ion).   Using the newly acquired nodule location, the Ion robotic system was adjusted to the new targeted location. I personally interpreted the cone beam CT and 3-D reconstruction. 
 
Transbronchial needle aspiration was performed with 19G Needle through the extended working channel catheter.  Total 1 samples were collected.  Samples sent for Cytology.
 
Radial EBUS was performed to confirm that the location of the nodule is Concentric after initial needle puncture into the lesion.  The following features were noted: continuous margin, heterogenous echotexture.
 
Once a tunnel had been created into the lesion with TBNA as above, Transbronchial microwave ablation was performed of the nodule as below. 
 
Modality	Tools	Setting/Mode	Duration	Results
Microwave 	Medium Antenna 	90*C	20:00 min	Transbronchial Ablation of Nodule
 
 
Subsequently, RB2 was engaged.  And microwave catheter was placed in the lateral superior aspect of the lung mass. CBCT was done to confirm the location. 
 
Modality	Tools	Setting/Mode	Duration	Results
Microwave 	Medium Antenna 	90*C	10:00 min	Transbronchial Ablation of Nodule
 
Subsequently, RB1 was engaged.  And microwave catheter was placed in the superior medial aspect of the lung mass. CBCT was done to confirm the location. 
 
Modality	Tools	Setting/Mode	Duration	Results
Microwave 	Medium Antenna 	90*C	10:00 min	Transbronchial Ablation of Nodule
 
Cone Beam CT was performed: 3-D reconstructions were performed on an independent workstation.  Cios Spin system was used for evaluation of nodule location.  Low dose spin was performed to acquire CT imaging.  This was passed on to Ion platform system for reconstruction and nodule location.  The 3D images was interpreted on an independent workstation (Ion).   Using the newly acquired nodule location, the Ion robotic system was adjusted to the new targeted location. I personally interpreted the cone beam CT and 3-D reconstruction. The images confirmed tool-in-lesion. 
 
The patient tolerated the procedure well.  There were no immediate complications.  At the conclusion of the operation, the patient was extubated in the operating room and Transported to the recovery room in stable condition. 
 
SPECIMEN(S): 
- RUL mass TBNA (cyto)
 
 
IMPRESSION/PLAN: Tammy Adams is a 63 year old-year-old female who presents for bronchoscopy for lung nodules.
RLL nodule and RUL mass underwent TBNA and MWA. 
 
- f/u CXR
- admit to medicine for observation
- monitor for post-ablation pain 
- start empiric abx (IV unasyn as inpatient, po moxifloxacin as an outpatient) 
 
 
Duane Johnson , MD, PhD
12/16/2025

diagnostic_bronchoscopy.inspection_findings: Trachea (Middle/Distal), Right Mainstem, and Bronchus Intermedius cleared of mucus

outcomes.follow_up_plan_text: f/u CXR, admit to medicine for observation, monitor for post-ablation pain, start empiric abx

lines.selection_reason: Therapeutic aspiration of central airways (Trachea, RMS, BI) distinct from RUL ablation site. Modifier 59/XS justified.
Navigation (Ion) initiated and used to reach target. Planning documented.

lines.selection_reason: Radial EBUS used for peripheral lesion localization.

financial_analysis.mppr_assumptions: Multiple Procedure Payment Reduction (MPPR) logic applied: Primary (31641) at 100%, Secondary (31645) reduced by 50% of the difference from base endoscopy code if applicable, Add-ons (+31627, +31654) at 100%.

per_code.summary: Primary code for microwave ablation of RUL tumor. Highest valued therapeutic procedure.
Therapeutic aspiration of central airways (distinct from RUL lesion). Reported separately with modifier 59.

documentation_evidence.snippet: Successful therapeutic aspiration was performed to clean out the Trachea... Right Mainstem... Bronchus Intermedius

per_code.summary: Bundled into 31641. Diagnostic biopsy of the same lesion (RUL mass) immediately preceding destruction is generally bundled per NCCI.

documentation_evidence.snippet: Transbronchial needle aspiration... Once a tunnel had been created... Transbronchial microwave ablation was performed

qa_flags.message: Code 31629 dropped as it bundles into 31641 for the same anatomic target.

rules_applied.details: CT guidance/Fluoro 77012 dropped as guidance is covered by Navigation (+31627) and bundled imaging.

global_comments: TBNA (31629) of RUL mass bundled into 31641 (Destruction of RUL mass).
Therapeutic aspiration (31645) reported separately due to distinct central airway clearance.
Navigation and Radial EBUS add-ons reported.
Correction: Removed erroneous 'cao_interventions_detail' entry (Laser) which conflicted with the primary peripheral microwave ablation documented in 'peripheral_ablation'.

note_text: DATE OF PROCEDURE: 12/16/2025   CC Referred Physician: Self, Referred No address on file   INDICATION FOR OPERATION: Sarah Jenkins is a 54 year old-year-old female who presents with Pleural Effusion. The nature, purpose, risks, benefits and alternatives to Chest Ultrasound and Chest tube placement were discussed with the patient in detail. Patient indicated a wish to proceed with procedure and informed consent was signed.   CONSENT : Obtained before the procedure. Its indications and potential complications and alternatives were discussed with the patient or surrogate. The patient or surrogate read and signed the provided consent form / provided consent over the phone. The consent was witnessed by an assisting medical professional.   PREOPERATIVE DIAGNOSIS: Pleural Effusion POSTOPERATIVE DIAGNOSIS: Same as preoperative diagnosis - see above.   PROCEDURE:  76604 Ultrasound, chest (includes mediastinum), real time with image documentation 32557 Insert catheter pleura with imaging (chest tube)   76604 was performed on the right side   ATTENDING:  John Smith, MD   ASSISTANT:   Mary Clark  MD   Support Staff: RN: Bedside RN   MONITORING : Pulse oximetry, heart rate, telemetry, and BP were continuously monitored by an independent trained observer that was present throughout the entire procedure.   PROCEDURE IN DETAIL: All procedure related images were saved and archived in Media folder on Onedrive behind UCSD firewall, relevant images are also uploaded to PACS system or in the media section of the patient's chart.   PATIENT POSITION: ‌ Supine  ‌ Sitting   X ‌ Lateral Decubitus: ‌ Left X‌ Right   CHEST ULTRASOUND FINDINGS:  X ‌ Image saved and up loaded to epic media tab Hemithorax:   X ‌ Right ‌ Left   Pleural Effusion: Volume:       ‌ None  ‌ Minimal  ‌ Small ‌ Moderate X ‌ Large Echogenicity:   ‌X Anechoic  ‌ Hypoechoic  ‌ Isoechoic ‌ Hyperechoic Loculations:  ‌ X None  ‌Thin  ‌ Thick Diaphragmatic Motion: X ‌ Normal  ‌ Diminished;  ‌ Absent  Lung: Lung sliding before procedure:   X ‌ Present ‌ Absent Lung sliding post procedure:   X ‌ Present ‌ Absent Lung consolidation/atelectasis: ‌ X Present  ‌ Absent Pleura:  ‌ X Normal  ‌ Thick ‌ Nodular   Insertion site prepped and draped in sterile fashion.   ANESTHESIA:  Lidocaine 1%: 10__ ml     Other: ______ Entry Site: X ‌ Right 7-8_ Intercostal Space   ‌ Left ___ Intercostal Space ‌ Mid-clavicular   ‌ Mid-axillary  X ‌ Mid-scapular  ‌ Other:   Size:  ‌ 6Fr  ‌ 8Fr  ‌ 12FR  X ‌ 14Fr  ‌ 16Fr  ‌ 18Fr  ‌ 24Fr   ‌ 32 Fr  ‌ Other: Sutured: ‌X  Yes ‌ No   PROCEDURE FINDINGS: A  pigtail catheter was inserted using the Seldinger technique. Entry into the pleural space was confirmed with the easy removal of minimal serous appearing pleural fluid. A guidewire was inserted using the introducer needle pointed in the apical posterior direction. The introducer needle was then removed. A dilator was then inserted over the wire with a twisting motion in order to form a tract for catheter insertion. The dilator was removed and the pigtail catheter (with trochar) was advanced over the guidewire. The catheter was inserted into the chest until all catheter holes were well within the chest. The guidewire and trochar were then removed.  The tube was then attached to the collection drain apparatus and secured in place with suture and covered.   Fluid Removed: 1250_ ml ‌X  Serous  ‌ Serosanguinous ‌ Bloody  ‌ Chylous ‌ Other:   Pleural pressures:  If not measured, please check here ‌X Opening:   cmH20   500 ml:      cmH20   1000ml:     cmH20       1500ml:     cmH20   2000ml      cmH20.          Drainage device:   ‌X Pleurovac    ‌ Drainage Bag  ‌ Heimlich Valve  ‌ Pneumostat ‌ Other: Suction: ‌ X No ‌Yes, - ___ cmH20   CHEST ULTRASOUND FINDINGS: X ‌ Image saved and uploaded to epic media tab Hemithorax:   X ‌ Right ‌ Left   Pleural Effusion: Volume:       ‌ X None  ‌ Minimal ‌ Small  ‌ Moderate  ‌ Large Echogenicity:   ‌ Anechoic  ‌ Hypoechoic  ‌ Isoechoic ‌ Hyperechoic Loculations:  ‌ None  ‌Thin  ‌ Thick Diaphragmatic Motion: X ‌ Normal  ‌ Diminished ‌ Absent  Lung: Lung sliding before procedure:   X ‌ Present ‌ Absent Lung sliding post procedure: X  ‌ Present ‌ Absent Lung consolidation/atelectasis: ‌ Present  X‌ Absent Pleura: X ‌ Normal ‌ Thick  ‌ Nodular   SPECIMEN(S): ‌X  LDH                        X ‌Glucose    X   ‌T. Protein   X  ‌Cholesterol ‌X Cell Count   ‌ ADA             ‌Triglycerides            ‌Amylase ‌X Gram Stain/ Culture         ‌‌AFB                         ‌Fungal Culture ‌X Cytology      ‌Flow Cytometry                               ‌Other:   CXR ordered: ‌X  Yes ‌ No   COMPLICATIONS: X ‌None ‌Bleeding-EBL: ___ ml ‌Pneumothorax ‌Re-Expansion Pulmonary Edema ‌Other:   IMPRESSION/PLAN: Sarah Jenkins is a 54 year old-year-old female who presents for Chest Ultrasound and Chest tube placement. The patient tolerated the procedure well. There were no immediate complications.   DISPOSITION: Nursing Unit [ ] f/u CXR [ ] f/u pleural fluid studies [ ] chest tube to water seal [ ] small bore flushing protocol   John Smith, MD 12/16/2025

note_text:
DATE OF PROCEDURE: 12/16/2025
 
CC Referred Physician:  Self, Referred
No address on file
 
INDICATION FOR OPERATION:  Vince Yound  is a 65 year old-year-old male who presents with lung mass.  The nature, purpose, risks, benefits and alternatives to Bronchoscopy were discussed with the patient in detail.  Patient indicated a wish to proceed with surgery and informed consent was signed.
 
CONSENT : Obtained before the procedure. Its indications and potential complications and alternatives were discussed with the patient or surrogate. The patient or surrogate read and signed the provided consent form / provided consent over the phone. The consent was witnessed by an assisting medical professional.
 
PREOPERATIVE DIAGNOSIS: J98.09 Other diseases of bronchus, not elsewhere classified
 
POSTOPERATIVE DIAGNOSIS:  J98.09 Other diseases of bronchus, not elsewhere classified
 
PROCEDURE:  
31645 Therapeutic aspiration initial episode
31641 Destruction of tumor OR relief of stenosis by any method other than excision (eg. laser therapy, cryotherapy)
 
 
 
ATTENDING:  
Duane Johnson MD PhD
 
ASSISTANT:   none
 
Support Staff: 
RN: Andrew Larson
RT: Mary Moore 
 
ANESTHESIA: 
General Anesthesia
 
MONITORING : Pulse oximetry, heart rate, telemetry, and BP were continuously monitored by an independent trained observer that was present throughout the entire procedure.
 
INSTRUMENT : 
Flexible Therapeutic Bronchoscope
 
ESTIMATED BLOOD LOSS:   None
 
COMPLICATIONS:    None
 
PROCEDURE IN DETAIL:
After the successful induction of anesthesia, a timeout was performed (confirming the patient's name, procedure type, and procedure location).  All procedure related images were saved and archived in Media folder on Onedrive behind UCSD firewall, relevant images are also uploaded to PACS system or in the media section of the patient's chart. 
 
PATIENT POSITION: . 
 
Initial Airway Inspection Findings:
 
Stent in RML orifice in good position. 
 
Successful therapeutic aspiration was performed to clean out the Right Mainstem, Bronchus Intermedius , and Left Mainstem from mucus. 
 
Endobronchial obstruction at Trachea (Distal 1/3), Right Mainstem, and Left Mainstem was treated with the following modalities:
 
Modality	Tools	Setting/Mode	Duration	Results
Electrocautery	 	 	 	 
APC	2.3 mm	straight	Pulse effect 4	ablated
Laser	 	 	 	 
CoreCath	 	 	 	 
Cryoprobe	 	 	 	 
 
Prior to treatment, affected airway was note to be 90% patent.  After treatment, the airway was 100% patent. 
 
 
The patient tolerated the procedure well.  There were no immediate complications.  At the conclusion of the operation, the patient was extubated in the operating room and Transported to the recovery room in stable condition. 
 
SPECIMEN(S): 
none
 
IMPRESSION/PLAN: Vince Yound  is a 65 year old-year-old male who presents for bronchoscopy for stent evaluation.
- repeat bronchoscopy in 4-6 weeks
- f/u in clinic with consideration to perform PDT
 
Duane Johnson , MD, PhD
12/16/2025

lines.description: Bronchoscopy; with therapeutic aspiration of tracheobronchial tree, initial
lines.selection_reason: Therapeutic aspiration of Bronchus Intermedius (BI) performed. Distinct anatomic site from 31641 (Trachea/RMS/LMS). Modifier XS applied to bypass NCCI bundling.

note_spans.snippet: Successful therapeutic aspiration was performed to clean out the... Bronchus Intermedius

financial_analysis.mppr_assumptions: Multiple Endoscopy Rule (MER) applies. 31641 paid at 100%. 31645 subject to reduction (standard calculation typically (Secondary RVU - Base Endoscopy RVU) * 0.5 + Base RVU, or simple 50% depending on payer). Estimate reflects approximate reduction.

per_code.summary: Supported by use of APC to treat endobronchial obstruction at multiple sites (Trachea, RMS, LMS) with documented improvement in patency.

Supported by 'successful therapeutic aspiration' of mucus. While often bundled into 31641, the note documents aspiration of the Bronchus Intermedius (BI), which was not treated with APC (31641). This represents a distinct anatomic site, justifying modifier XS.

rules_applied.description: General anesthesia provided by Anesthesiologist; moderate sedation codes (99152/99153) omitted.

global_comments: Patient has a stent in RML (inspected only); no stent code reported as no manipulation occurred.
General anesthesia precludes billing moderate sedation.

metadata.notes: Stent inspection noted (RML). PDT considered for future.

note_text: DATE OF PROCEDURE: 12/16/2025   CC Referred Physician: Self, Referred No address on file   INDICATION FOR OPERATION: Michael Jackson is a 72 year old-year-old male who presents with Recurrent Pleural Effusion. The nature, purpose, risks, benefits and alternatives to Chest Ultrasound and Chest tube placement were discussed with the patient in detail. Patient indicated a wish to proceed with procedure and informed consent was signed.   CONSENT : Obtained before the procedure. Its indications and potential complications and alternatives were discussed with the patient or surrogate. The patient or surrogate read and signed the provided consent form / provided consent over the phone. The consent was witnessed by an assisting medical professional.   PREOPERATIVE DIAGNOSIS: Pleural Effusion (Complex) POSTOPERATIVE DIAGNOSIS: Same as preoperative diagnosis - see above.   PROCEDURE:  76604 Ultrasound, chest (includes mediastinum), real time with image documentation 32557 Insert catheter pleura with imaging (chest tube)   76604 was performed on the left side   ATTENDING:  John Smith, MD   ASSISTANT:   Mary Clark  MD   Support Staff: RN: Bedside RN   MONITORING : Pulse oximetry, heart rate, telemetry, and BP were continuously monitored by an independent trained observer that was present throughout the entire procedure.   PROCEDURE IN DETAIL: All procedure related images were saved and archived in Media folder on Onedrive behind UCSD firewall, relevant images are also uploaded to PACS system or in the media section of the patient's chart.   PATIENT POSITION: X ‌ Supine  ‌ Sitting   ‌ Lateral Decubitus: ‌ Right ‌ Left   CHEST ULTRASOUND FINDINGS:  X ‌ Image saved and up loaded to epic media tab Hemithorax:   ‌ Right X ‌ Left   Pleural Effusion: Volume:       ‌ None  ‌ Minimal  ‌ Small ‌ X Moderate ‌ Large Echogenicity:   ‌ Anechoic  ‌ X Hypoechoic  ‌ Isoechoic ‌ Hyperechoic Loculations:  ‌ None  ‌ X Thin  ‌ Thick Diaphragmatic Motion: ‌ Normal  X ‌ Diminished;  ‌ Absent  Lung: Lung sliding before procedure:   X ‌ Present ‌ Absent Lung sliding post procedure:   X ‌ Present ‌ Absent Lung consolidation/atelectasis: ‌ X Present  ‌ Absent Pleura:  ‌ Normal  X ‌ Thick ‌ Nodular   Insertion site prepped and draped in sterile fashion.   ANESTHESIA:  Lidocaine 1%: 8__ ml     Other: ______ Entry Site: ‌ Right ___ Intercostal Space   X ‌ Left 5-6 Intercostal Space ‌ Mid-clavicular   X ‌ Mid-axillary  ‌ Mid-scapular  ‌ Other:   Size:  ‌ 6Fr  ‌ 8Fr  ‌ 12FR  ‌ 14Fr  X ‌ 16Fr  ‌ 18Fr  ‌ 24Fr   ‌ 32 Fr  ‌ Other: Sutured: ‌X  Yes ‌ No   PROCEDURE FINDINGS: A  pigtail catheter was inserted using the Seldinger technique. Entry into the pleural space was confirmed with the easy removal of minimal serous appearing pleural fluid. A guidewire was inserted using the introducer needle pointed in the apical posterior direction. The introducer needle was then removed. A dilator was then inserted over the wire with a twisting motion in order to form a tract for catheter insertion. The dilator was removed and the pigtail catheter (with trochar) was advanced over the guidewire. The catheter was inserted into the chest until all catheter holes were well within the chest. The guidewire and trochar were then removed.  The tube was then attached to the collection drain apparatus and secured in place with suture and covered.   Fluid Removed: 650_ ml ‌  Serous  ‌X Serosanguinous ‌ Bloody  ‌ Chylous ‌ Other:   Pleural pressures:  If not measured, please check here ‌X Opening:   cmH20   500 ml:      cmH20   1000ml:     cmH20       1500ml:     cmH20   2000ml      cmH20.          Drainage device:   ‌X Pleurovac    ‌ Drainage Bag  ‌ Heimlich Valve  ‌ Pneumostat ‌ Other: Suction: ‌ No X ‌Yes, - 20_ cmH20   CHEST ULTRASOUND FINDINGS: X ‌ Image saved and uploaded to epic media tab Hemithorax:   ‌ Right X ‌ Left   Pleural Effusion: Volume:       ‌ None  ‌ Minimal ‌ X Small  ‌ Moderate  ‌ Large Echogenicity:   ‌ Anechoic  ‌X Hypoechoic  ‌ Isoechoic ‌ Hyperechoic Loculations:  ‌ None  ‌X Thin  ‌ Thick Diaphragmatic Motion: ‌ Normal  X ‌ Diminished ‌ Absent  Lung: Lung sliding before procedure:   X ‌ Present ‌ Absent Lung sliding post procedure: X  ‌ Present ‌ Absent Lung consolidation/atelectasis: ‌ X Present  ‌ Absent Pleura: ‌ Normal  X‌ Thick  ‌ Nodular   SPECIMEN(S): ‌X  LDH                        X ‌Glucose    X   ‌T. Protein   X  ‌Cholesterol ‌X Cell Count   ‌ ADA             ‌Triglycerides            ‌Amylase ‌X Gram Stain/ Culture         X  ‌AFB                         ‌X Fungal Culture ‌X Cytology      ‌Flow Cytometry                               ‌Other:   CXR ordered: ‌X  Yes ‌ No   COMPLICATIONS: X ‌None ‌Bleeding-EBL: ___ ml ‌Pneumothorax ‌Re-Expansion Pulmonary Edema ‌Other:   IMPRESSION/PLAN: Michael Jackson is a 72 year old-year-old male who presents for Chest Ultrasound and Chest tube placement. The patient tolerated the procedure well. There were no immediate complications.   DISPOSITION: Nursing Unit [ ] f/u CXR [ ] f/u pleural fluid studies [ ] chest tube to water seal [ ] small bore flushing protocol   John Smith, MD 12/16/2025
